Issues.Title: [v4] Always honor git ignore files
Issues.Body: Automatic content detection looks at your git ignore files but only when in a git repo. We want to _always_ honor them even when not in a git repo as it's not uncommon to do some small setup / development before initializing a git repo.

#### ‚ÜóÔ∏è browserify-sign (_indirect_, 4.2.1 ‚Üí 4.2.3) ¬∑ [Repo](https://github.com/browserify/browserify-sign) ¬∑ [Changelog](https://github.com/browserify/browserify-sign/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md)
Security Advisories üö®

üö® browserify-sign upper bound check issue in `dsaVerify` leads to a signature forgery attack

Summary

An upper bound check issue in dsaVerify function allows an attacker to construct signatures that can be successfully verified by any public key, thus leading to a signature forgery attack.

Details

In dsaVerify function, it checks whether the value of the signature is legal by calling function checkValue, namely, whether r and s are both in the interval [1, q - 1]. However, the second line of the checkValue function wrongly checks the upper bound of the passed parameters, since the value of b.cmp(q) can only be 0, 1 and -1, and it can never be greater than q.

In this way, although the values of s cannot be 0, an attacker can achieve the same effect as zero by setting its value to q, and then send (r, s) = (1, q) to pass the verification of any public key.

Impact

All places in this project that involve DSA verification of user-input signatures will be affected by this vulnerability.

Fix PR:

Since the temporary private fork was deleted, here's a webarchive of the PR discussion and diff pages: PR webarchive.zip

Behavior changes for URL objects

It serializes URL objects as follows since this version. The result of serialization may be changed if you are passing URL object values into the serialize-javascript.

const serialize = require("serialize-javascript");

serialize({u: new URL("http://example.com/")}); // '{"u":new URL("http://example.com/")}'

Thank you @rrdelaney for this release.

Issues.Title: [v4] Missing CSS properties in utility classes
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please provide all of the information requested below. We're a small team and without all of this information it's not possible for us to help and your bug report will be closed. -->

**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?**

For example: v4.0.0-alpha.3

**What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?**

vite 5.1.5

**What version of Node.js are you using?**

v20


**Reproduction URL**

https://stackblitz.com/edit/vitejs-vite-iarmom

**Describe your issue**

Firsty let me congratulate you on v4, I really love the changes and the direction to the CSS-native feeling! I've actually had similiar ideas with [winduum.dev](https://winduum.dev), utilizing CSS properties, color-mix etc. via [TailwindCSS plugin](https://github.com/winduum/winduum/blob/main/plugin/index.js)

I just had a quick look at v4 locally and maybe found a bug, but not sure though, could be also inteded.

Currently the CSS properties defined in `@theme` are not used in the utility classes? I would expect it to work this way since the properties are defined in `:root` for usage. Wouldn't they be redundant this way if not used in custom CSS?

So when defining properties like this

```css
@theme {
    --color-primary: blue;
    --color-secondary: red;
    --font-weight-bold: 700;
}
```

I would expect the result be

```css
.text-primary {
    color: var(--color-primary);
}

.text-secondary {
    color: var(--color-secondary);
}

.font-bold {
    font-weight: var(--font-weight-bold);
}
```

This allows more control over the utilities, you could for example change the color if needed from the parent with [--color-primary:red], or on hover etc.

It's possible to define CSS properties in `@theme` now, but you would have to define them in :root elsewhere and that seems redundant.

Also just wondering why introducing the `@theme` at-rule? Wouldn't be better just use the layer theme and properties defined in there under :root or :host? Seems more CSS friendly, also opens possibilities like `@import "custom-theme.css" layer(theme);`
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[v4] Missing CSS properties in utility classes " (#13114)

Issues.Body:
**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?**
v.next

**What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?**
vite (v5.1.5), @builder.io/qwik (v1.5.1), @builder.io/qwik-city (v1.5.1), @tailwindcss/vite (v.next)

**What version of Node.js are you using?**
v20.9.0

**What browser are you using?**
Chrome, Safari, Edge

**What operating system are you using?**
macOS

**Reproduction URL** 
https://codesandbox.io/p/devbox/loving-glade-zdpd88?file=%2Fsrc%2Froutes%2Findex.tsx

**Describe your issue**

I'm experimenting with TailwindCSS version 4 and have encountered an issue: certain styles don't seem to apply correctly. Upon investigating, I discovered that the styles defined in "preflight.css" take precedence over other TailwindCSS styles. To illustrate this problem, "preflight.css" sets that "h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6" inherit the font size through the style "font-size: inherit". This means that if you assign the "text-3xl" class to an "h1" element, the style intended by "text-3xl" is overridden by the one established in "preflight.css".

Issues.Title: Spacing utilities to px instead of rem by default
Issues.Body:
### Discussed in https://github.com/tailwindlabs/tailwindcss/discussions/13098
Originally posted by **KocsisGabor** March 6, 2024 Relevant but closed issue on this topic. #800 I'm honestly surprised, I must assume there's something I don't know because choosing rem for spacing does not make any sense to me. Apparently rem was chosen because it allows proportional resizing of everything, in other words, it allows us to zoom, exactly like how every browser allows their every user to zoom. Is there a website which relies on the root font-size to change the zoom? I doubt it, it seems pointless to me. ## Why do we have rem units? If the websites are using rem units for font-sizes, then the users can change the default browser font-size in case they have poor eyesight, which allows them to consume content easier on the internet. This is literally the only reason we have rem units! Most web developers probably have perfect eyesight because changing the default browser font-size most of the time either has no effect or it zooms the websites. This makes this setting rather useless since pretty much every browser has a dedicated default zoom feature anyway, and the browser zoom can easily be overwritten by the user, for example, with ctrl+wheel. I don't really understand why most developers use this unit incorrectly. The only change needed when the rem units became supported was to change some font-size to rem instead of pixels. This is pretty much a ~30 line change in CSS for complex websites. Instead, the developers decided to either overwrite the root font-size so they can pointlessly use rem units just because they read somewhere that they should, or they don't overwrite it but use rem everywhere again just to lose its intended functionality. Why did the Tailwind developers think that it would be a good idea to change the border width on a button, a shadow under a card, or the distance between nav items just because the user has changed the default font-size? ## What would be the effect of this change? Currently, changing the browser default font-size just zooms exactly like how the browser can zoom. If the spacing units were to change to pixels, nothing would change if the user didn't touch the default font-size. Pretty much every Tailwind website would look exactly the same. However, if the user has changed the default font-size, for example, to 20 pixels, this would mean that most Tailwind websites would show text in 125% size instead of zooming the websites to 125%. This should be the intended effect of changing the default font-size, not a redundant zoom. Tailwind is popular, so if the spacing units were to change to pixels instead of rem in Tailwind, that would instantly solve this problem on countless websites. Would this break websites? Maybe, there are surely websites where the root font-size has been overwritten for some reason, but pretty much all of these websites use rem incorrectly. There are probably also websites where they overwrite the root font-size but also allow the user to change it with a button or something. Currently, this button in these websites zooms the content, and after the change, it would have the probably intended effect of changing the font-size (this is a positive effect in my opinion). The users who decide to change the default font-size would have a better experience on the internet. ## What needs to be changed? The default config should have this theme.spacing property: ```javascript spacing: { px: '1px', 0: '0px', 0.5: '2px', 1: '4px', 1.5: '6px', 2: '8px', 2.5: '10px', 3: '12px', 3.5: '14px', 4: '16px', 5: '20px', 6: '24px', 7: '28px', 8: '32px', 9: '36px', 10: '40px', 11: '44px', 12: '48px', 14: '56px', 16: '64px', 20: '80px', 24: '96px', 28: '112px', 32: '128px', 36: '144px', 40: '160px', 44: '176px', 48: '192px', 52: '208px', 56: '224px', 60: '240px', 64: '256px', 72: '288px', 80: '320px', 96: '384px', } ``` Most Tailwind users need to change nothing if this change goes live. Those developers who have actually affected website needs to change their Tailwind config to have the rem spacing values. ## Conclusion Even if we assume that for some reason an unreasonable amount of websites need their interface to zoom when a user has changed the default font-size, this change would still be a positive change because the default should be what's best in most cases, not what can be useful in some weird edge cases especially when it takes about ~1 minute to change the pixel values to rem for a developer in their own config file. **Important**: This change would not affect font-sizes and some few other properties like max-w-md, which would still use rem units. This change would only affect the spacing properties like margin and some other properties like border-width. Sorry if this was a bit aggressive, I'm just really frustrated that I needed to make this issue at all.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Spacing utilities to px instead of rem by default" (#13108)

Issues.Title: Important modifier doesn't work on `@apply` rules for custom utilities and components
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please provide all of the information requested below. We're a small team and without all of this information it's not possible for us to help and your bug report will be closed. -->

**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?**

v3.4.1

**What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?**

N/A

**What version of Node.js are you using?**

v19.8.1

**What browser are you using?**

Chrome

**What operating system are you using?**

macOS

**Reproduction URL**

https://play.tailwindcss.com/N1pmDRsMmo

**Describe your issue**

This may be intended behavior‚Äîif so, apologies for filing this as an issue. I couldn't find any previous discussions or issues about this, though.

The important-modifier doesn't work for `@apply` rules that are part of custom utilities or components. For example, if I've done:

```css
@layer utilities {
  .foo {
    @apply text-lg underline;
  }
}
```

then `class="!foo"` will apply the `text-lg` and `underline` rules but without the `!important` syntax. The same limitation is true if I instead use `addUtilities()` or `addComponents()` in my Tailwind config, like:

```js
addUtilities({
  '.foo': {
    '@apply text-lg underline': ''
  }
})
```

On the other hand, any rules for `.foo` declared with normal CSS syntax (or normal CSS-in-JS syntax) _will_ get `!important` in the `class="!foo"` case.

It would be nice if the important-modifier worked with `@apply` rules in custom utilities and components. The `!important` would of course have to go on the actual property-value pairs, which are sometimes nested in at-rules or media queries (with syntax like `@apply sm:underline`); I don't know whether that would present a major challenge.

In anticipation of the argument that one simply shouldn't use `@apply` in this way:

In my opinion, this sort of situation‚Äîbuilding new utilities/components from existing ones‚Äîis precisely where `@apply` really shines! This technique lets you keep everything "in sync," so that if, for example, the definition of `text-lg` ever changes, then that change cascades to `.foo` in my code above. (And you'll even get an error if you try to `@apply` something that doesn't exist, which I'd argue is helpful here.) I know that one can use the `theme()` directive to refer to theme-values, but that doesn't let you do things like weave in custom variants with complex selectors (my typical use-cases for this technique are considerably more complicated than the simple example I've given).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Important modifier doesn't work on `@apply` rules for custom utilities and components" (#13102)

Issues.Title: [v4] Only output `@property foo` once instead of N times
Issues.Body:
This PR improves the performance of the AST to CSS generation.

This now only outputs `@property foo` once, if it was already generated at the top-level then it will not be generated again.

On the tailwindcss.com codebase, this reduces the CSS generation (before the Lightning CSS step) time from `~6ms` to `~3ms`.

If we weren't using Lightning CSS at all, then it would reduce the generated CSS size from ~28k lines of code to ~14k lines of code (again, on the tailwindcss.com repo).

This means that we are sending fewer bytes to Lightning CSS to optimize, making the whole process a bit faster.

Issues.Title: cluttered layout on quick scroll or any update on page
Issues.Body: **What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?** v3.4.1 **What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?** postcss 8.4.35 Next.js 14.1.2, **What version of Node.js are you using?** v20.2.0 **What browser are you using?** For example: Chrome **What operating system are you using?** For example: macOS **Reproduction URL** - with tailwind: https://double-rendering-minimal.vercel.app/pcr - without tailwind: https://double-rendering-minimal.vercel.app/pcr-no-tailwind - issue recording (as not reproducible on all devices): https://drive.google.com/file/d/1HhvPlCAwkIPjIyMiewO7BHyATi8RNt1s/view?usp=drive_link - github link: https://github.com/Smiles-ai/rendering-issue-demo **Describe your issue** We are encountering a cluttered layout issue when quickly scrolling or updating the page (however, repetitive elements are not present in the DOM, it's solely a layout issue). We have built the same layout using two screens: one utilizing Next.js + Tailwind CSS and the other using Next.js + normal CSS. The issue only manifests in the repository where Tailwind CSS is used. Additionally, this problem is not reproducible on all devices. I am sharing a screen recording of the issue and device information. Note: The cluttered layout issue is not limited to the SVG teeth chart; it is randomly occurring on all elements. Additionally, this problem is not confined to this specific page; it is happening on all other pages as well. We are just sharing a sample page link for demonstration purposes. - Device details: Device: OnePlus Nord CE2 (IV2201) Android Version: 13 (Oxygen OS 13) Screen Size: 6.43 inches Browser: Chrome 122.0.6261.90 We have attempted to connect the Chrome debugger tool to inspect the mobile code. However, in the DOM, the cluttered layout changes are not reflected. Furthermore, since this issue is limited to very few devices, it is proving to be quite challenging to debug. Additionally, we have tried removing the teeth chart and other elements that frequently exhibit the cluttered layout, but the issue persists in other elements.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "cluttered layout on quick scroll or any update on page" (#13083)

Issues.Title: Important selector does not modify
Issues.Body:
**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?**

3.4.1

**What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?**

Svelte 4.2.8 / Vite 5.0.8

**What version of Node.js are you using?**

20

**What browser are you using?**

Firefox / Chrome

**What operating system are you using?**

NixOS

**Reproduction URL**

https://play.tailwindcss.com/J68KhTQ5z0

**Describe your issue**

I'm building a widget which gets embedded into other websites. These websites may have other style classes set which then override Tailwind's class names. Like this:

```
.p-4 {
  padding: 4rem !important;
}
```

(Yes, they have set their utility classes with `!important`)

I'm using Tailwind's [important selector](https://tailwindcss.com/docs/configuration#selector-strategy) in my config. This works as long as the main website stylesheet does not use `!important` in their interfering class names. Once they do, their styles are more important than mine. I can't change their styles.

Ideally, I'd love a way to set a selector _and_ apply the `!important` modifier to all styles at the same time. That way, I won't override the website's styles and they won't override mine. I know I can add `!` to all classes, but that's a bit tedious and will be one more thing I need to think about while building this.

Maybe similar to https://github.com/tailwindlabs/tailwindcss/issues/11331
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Important selector does not modify " (#13060)

Issues.Title: Extending animation doesn't work using standalone CLI
Issues.Body:
**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?** v3.4.1 **What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?** I'm using standalone CLI throught pytailwindcss inside a docker container **What browser are you using?** Chrome **What operating system are you using?** Ubuntu 22.04 **Reproduction** It's a problem of configuration. I can't provide a reproduction URL but, instead, I will try to make a recipe to repeat the process that I follow. * Install tailwindcss standalone * Use `tailwindcss init` to create a configuration file * Add the following config: ```js /** @type {import('tailwindcss').Config} */ module.exports = { content: ['testfile.html'], theme: { extend: { animation: { wiggle: 'wiggle 1s ease-in-out infinite', }, keyframes: { wiggle: { '0%, 100%': {transform: 'rotate(-3deg)'}, '50%': {transform: 'rotate(3deg)'} } }, colors: { 'test-color': '#123' } }, } } ``` * Create the following html file with the name `testfile.html` ```html Title
a
``` * Execute tailwindcss with the command `tailwindcss -c tailwind.config.js -o ./tailwind.css` **Describe your issue** Following the reproduction steps you will see that the dynamic class w-[87px] was created, the bg-test-color class too, **but wiggle doesn't appear** in the css. So I conclude that is only a problem of the animation part of configuration. ![image](https://github.com/tailwindlabs/tailwindcss/assets/18660829/26a6e4ba-5563-42fb-92f5-8284e471e23e) Thinking about I was wrong with my config, I used the example of the official docs obtaining the same results.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Extending animation doesn't work using standalone CLI" (#13063)

Issues.Title: Specificity Not Working With Pseudo Attributes
Issues.Body:
**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?**

"tailwindcss": "^3.4.1"

**What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?**

"astro": "^4.3.0",
"@astrojs/tailwind": "^5.1.0",

**What version of Node.js are you using?**

v21.6.2

**What browser are you using?**

Firefox

**What operating system are you using?**

Ubuntu

**Reproduction URL**

https://play.tailwindcss.com/B1aR8yskfi

**Describe your issue**

I noticed that specificity doesn't play nicely with pseudo attributes like `translate` or `rotate`.  You would expect the class from the outer `div` to dominate the `translate` value of the `h1`, just like it would work for non-pseudo attributes.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Specificity Not Working With Pseudo Attributes" (#13061)
